Otherwise, let w_1 and w_2 have vertex sequences w_1 = Î±_1 Î±_2 â‹¯Î±_m+1 and w_2 = Î²_1 Î²_2 â‹¯Î²_nÎ²_1, and let k be the index of the final appearance of Î²_1 in w_1.     Î±_k+1â‹¯Î±_m+1.

     The walk w_1 w_2 has length m + n and is said to consist of w_2 nested into w_1 (off vertex Î²_1). The vertex sequence of w_1  w_2 is formed by replacing the final appearance of Î²_1 in w_1 by the entire vertex sequence of w_2.

sentence:
A generalised tree  consists of a root node T plus a (possibly empty) ordered sequence of hedges, where a hedge is an ordered sequence of generalised trees:

    = [T.root, [ H_1, H_2, â€¦, H_n ] ], 
    _i     = [T_i,1,T_i,2,â€¦, T_i,k_i].

     Here n â‰¥ 0 is the number of hedges proceeding from T, and k_i â‰¥ 0 is the number of generalised trees in the hedge _i. Adopting standard terminology, we say that each of the nodes _i,1,â€¦,_i,k_i is a child node of T, and has T as a parent. A node that has no children is a leaf node. Given a node n, nodes in the same hedge as n are said to be siblings (specifically, right or left siblings, according to their position in the hedge relative to n).


     Every node in  has a depth and a height: the depth of a node n is equal to the length of a path from n to T, and the height of n is the length of the longest downward path from n to a leaf node. The height of the entire tree  is defined to be the height of T.root.

     A subtree of  consists of a node n and all its descendants (i.e.Â all children, grandchildren, etc.) in . We denote the subtree rooted at node n by t(n): thus t() =, while for nâ‰ , t(n) is a proper subtree of .

sentence:
Given a digraph , a syntax tree over  is a generalised tree  together with a collection of elements of W_, one associated with each node in . We denote the walk associated with node n by n.contents, and define the contents of  (as distinct from the contents of its root node) to be


    T.contents = T.root.contentsH_n.contentsâ‹¯H_2.contentsH_1.contents,

where the contents of a hedge are given by

    H_i.contents = T_i,1.contentsT_i,2.contentsâ‹¯T_i,k_i.contents.


     The syntax tree  is valid for a walk w if and only if it satisfies the following conditions:


  (i) T.contents = w,
       
  (ii) h(H_i.contents) â‰  h(H_j.contents) for i â‰  j. In other words, no two hedges contain closed walks off the same vertex.

     The purpose of the second condition is to disallow syntax trees where several closed walks off the same vertex are placed in different hedges, rather than into different generalised trees within the same hedge.

Let  be a canonical syntax tree, and = [k_0,â€¦,k_D-1,0] a dressing signature of depth D. Then the local depth of a node n of  with respect to , denoted (n), is an integer between 0 and D inclusive, defined as follows. The root node  and all its immediate children have a local depth of 0, while every other node n has a local depth given by

    (n) =
    (p)  + 1   [c]
                  if (p.contents) â‰¤ k_(p) and
    
                  t(n_j).contents is [k_(p)+1,â€¦,0]-structured for 1 â‰¤ j â‰¤ i-1,

In a minor abuse of terminology, we will frequently refer to the local depth of a simple cycle s, which is to be understood as being shorthand for the local depth of the node containing s.

The Voronoi subdivision of a k-simplex divides it 
into k+1 regions, where region i consists of the 
points in the simplex for which i is the closest vertex.
Given a subdivision S of nÎ”_d-1, 
we subdivide each fine mixed cell S_1+â€¦  + S_n 
into regions R_1+â€¦ +R_n, where R_i is a 
region in the Voronoi subdivision of S_i.
The resulting subdivision of nÎ”_d-1 is called
the mixed Voronoi subdivision of S.

sentence:
[Multiplicities of edges and vertices in rooted or unrooted trees, see FigureÂ <ref>]
Let T, e, T_-, U_+, v_-, v_+ be as above. Then:


  -
The rooted multiplicity of the edge e in T , denoted by m_T(e) is the number of distinct edges in T that are mapped to e by some isomorphism of T (as a rooted tree).

  -
The rooted multiplicity of the vertex v_- in T_- , denoted by m_T_-(v_-) is the number of distinct vertices in T_- that are mapped to v_- by some isomorphism of T_- (as a rooted tree, rooted at the root of T).

  -
The unrooted multiplicity of v_+ in U_+ , denoted by n_U_+(v_+) is the number of distinct vertices in U_+ that are mapped to v_+ by some isomorphism of U_+ (as an unrooted tree).

sentence:
A graph is matchable if it has a perfect matching.
	An edge e âˆˆ E(G) is extendable
		if there exists a perfect matching of G
		which contains e.
	Otherwise, e is free .
	The extendable subgraph ( free subgraph ) of G is 
		the spanning subgraph containing all extendable (free) edges of G.

sentence:
If the extendable subgraph of a matchable graph G is connected,
		then G is elementary .
	A set S âŠ‚ V(G) is a barrier[We take the convention that the empty set is a barrier.]
		if the number of connected components 
		with an odd number of vertices
		in 
		G - S (denoted (G-S)) is equal to |S|.

	form H^(i+1) +.
If H^(i+1) is 1-extendable or H^(i) is 1-extendable and H^(i+1) is almost 1-extendable,
	recurse on H^(i+1) until Î¦(H^(i+1)) > p.
While this technique will generate all graphs in ^p_N_p, 
	it will generate each unlabeled graph several times.
In fact, the number of times an unlabeled H âˆˆ^p_N_p
	appears is at least the number of ear decompositions
	H_0 âŠ‚â‹¯âŠ‚ H_kâŠ‚ H
	which match the conditions of Corollary <ref>.
	
We will remove these redundancies in two ways.
First, we will augment using pair orbits of vertices in H^(i).
Second, we will reject some augmentations
	if they do not correspond with a â€œcanonical" 
	ear decomposition of the larger graph.
This technique is described in detail in <cit.>.	
	
	Let (H) be a function which takes a graph H âˆˆ^p
		and returns an ear  in H
		so that H - is in ^p.
	This function (H) is a canonical deletion
		if for any two H_1, H_2 âˆˆ^p so that H_1 â‰… H_2,
		there exists an isomorphism Ïƒ : H_1â†’ H_2
		that  maps (H_1) to (H_2).
	
	Given a canonical deletion (H), 
		the canonical ear decomposition at H
		is given by the following iterative construction:
		(i) Set H_0 = H and i = 0.
		(ii) While H^(i) is not a cycle, define H_i-1 = H^(i) - (H^(i)) 
		and decrement i.
	When this process terminates,
		what results is an ear decomposition 
	H_-kâŠ‚ H_-(k-1)âŠ‚â‹¯âŠ‚ H_-1âŠ‚ H_0
	where H_-k is isomorphic to a cycle and H_0 = H.

sentence:
For a graph H, the parameter d(H) := e(H)/v(H) is called the density of H, and m(H) := max{d(H') | H'âŠ† H} is the maximum density of H. A graph H is called strictly balanced if d(H) > d(H') for every H' âŠŠ H.

For iâˆˆ{1,2}, if v(H)â‰¥ i+1 we define d_i(H) := e(H)-i+1/v(H)-i to be the i-density of H. Similarly to the previous definitions, we define m_i(H) := max{d_i(H') | H'âŠ† H, v(H')â‰¥ i+1 } to be the maximum i-density of H, and a graph H is called strictly i-balanced if d_i(H) > d_i(H') for every H' âŠŠ H.

G with at most (b+1)(v(H)-1) vertices.

sentence: Let G=(V,E) be a multi-graph with vertex set V = {v_1, â€¦, v_n} and let f : V â†’â„•^+. We say that G is Alon-Tarsi f-choosable , or f-AT for brevity, if there exists a monomial c âˆ_i=1^n x_i^t_i in the expansion of P_G such that c â‰  0 (say, in â„) and t_i â‰¤ f(i)-1 for every 1 â‰¤ i â‰¤ n. If f(i)=k for every 1 â‰¤ i â‰¤ n, then we say that G is Alon-Tarsi k-choosable , or k-AT for brevity. The smallest integer k for which G is Alon-Tarsi k-choosable, denoted by AT(G), is called the Alon-Tarsi number of G .

sentence:
Vertices x^v and y^v of the polytope (n) are not adjacent if and only if the following conditions are satisfied.
	
		
  * There exists a city i (called left block ) such that the tours x and y on the coordinate i (coordinates i and i+1 for double blocks) have the form of U,L, or i = 1.
		
		
  * There exists a city j (called right block ) such that the tours x and y on the coordinate j (coordinates j-1 and j for double blocks) have the form of U,R, or j = n.
		
		We denote by i_a the first city after the left block: i_a = i+1 for single blocks and i_a = i+2 for double blocks.
		We denote by j_b the last city before the right block: j_b = i-1 for single blocks and j_b = j-2 for double blocks.
		
		Two blocks cut the encoding of the tours into three parts: the left (less than i_a), the central (from i_a to j_b) and the right (larger than j_b).
		
		
  * In the central part, the coordinates of x^0,1 and y^0,1 completely coincide: x^0,1_[i_a,j_b] = y^0,1_[i_a,j_b].
		
		We say that two tours
		
			
  * differ in the left part if x^0,1,sb_[1,i_a-1]â‰  y^0,1,sb_[1,i_a-1],
			
  * differ in the right part if x^0,1,sb_[j_b+1,n]â‰  y^0,1,sb_[j_b+1,n],
			
  * differ in the central part in ascending order if x^1,sb_[i_a,j_b]â‰  y^1,sb_[i_a,j_b],
			
  * differ in the central part in descending order if x^0,sb_[i_a,j_b]â‰  y^0,sb_[i_a,j_b].
		
		
		The remaining conditions are divided into four cases depending on the values of x^0,1_i and x^0,1_j.
		
		
			
  * If x^0,1_i = x^0,1_j = 1, then the tours differ
			
				
  * in the central part in ascending order;
				
  * in the left part, or in the central part in descending order, or in the right part.
			
		
			
  * If x^0,1_i = x^0,1_j = 0, then the tours differ
			
				
  * in the central part in descending order;
				
  * in the left part, or in the central part in ascending order, or in the right part.
			
		
			
  * If x^0,1_i = 1, x^0,1_j = 0, then the tours differ	
			
				
  * in the central part in ascending order or in the right part;
				
  * in the central part in descending order or in the left part.
			
		
			
  * If x^0,1_i = 0, x^0,1_j = 1, then the tours differ
		
			
				
  * in the central part in descending order or in the right part;
				
  * in the central part in ascending order or in the left part.
			
		
	
	Cities 1 and n can be considered in the encoding as visited in ascending or descending order, if required.

sentence:
Let G=(V,E) be a graph. An induced subgraph H of G
on m vertices is called p-full if its minimum
degree is at least p(m-1), and is called
p-co-full if its maximum degree is at most
p(m-1). Let f_p(G) be the largest number of vertices
in a p-full subgraph of G, and let g_p(G) be the
largest size of a p-full or p-co-full subgraph of
G. If p happens to be the density of G, then in
fact f_p(G)= f(G) and g_p(G) = g(G). Determining the
smallest possible values of f_p(G) and g_p(G) given
the number of edges and number of vertices in G can be
viewed as generalisations of the TurÃ¡n and of the
Ramsey problems, respectively, which comprise the case p
= 1; seeÂ <cit.> and the references
therein.


The positive p-discrepancy of G is defined to
be disc_p^+(G)=max_XâŠ†
VÎ´_p(X). The negative p-discrepancy of
G is disc_p^-(G)=max_XâŠ† V
(-Î´_p(X)). The p-discrepancy of G is
disc_p(G)=max(disc_p^+(G),
disc_p^-(G)). Finally, the
p-jumbledness of G is

    j_p(G)=max_XâŠ† V|Î´_p(X)|/| X|.

      at least two and is obtained by intersecting an arithmetic

m_h_i_j, h_i_j+1= (i_j+1, â€¦, i_n)
        
(1â‰¤ j â‰¤ n-2),

  over the common differences r of all arithmetic progressions

sentence:
Let d â‰¥ 1 be a dimension.  An algebraic set in ^d is any set of the form

    { x âˆˆ^d: P_1(x) =â€¦=P_m(x) = 0}

where P_1,â€¦,P_m: ^d â†’ are polynomials.  If one can take m=1, we call the algebraic set a hypersurface .  An algebraic set is irreducible if it cannot be expressed as the union of two strictly smaller algebraic sets.  An irreducible algebraic set will be referred to as an algebraic variety , or variety for short.

The intersection of any subset of ^d with ^d will be referred to as the real points of that subset.  A real algebraic variety is the real points V_ of a complex algebraic variety V.[Strictly speaking, because two different complex varieties may have the same real points, a real algebraic variety should really be viewed as a pair (V_,V) rather than just the set V_; however, we will abuse notation and identify a real algebraic variety with the set V_ of real points.]

sentence:
Suppose (,) has the Null Tangle Property and let T be any tagged triangulation of (,).
Then  

  * The fan _(T) is the rational part of the mutation fan _B(T).  In particular:  

  * The support of _(T) contains ^n.  

  * Every rational cone in _B(T) 
is a cone in _(T).

  * The full-dimensional cones in _B(T) are exactly the full-dimensional cones in _(T).

  * Every codimension-1 cone in _(T) is a cone in _B(T). 

  * The -vector fan of the transpose B(T)^T is the set of all cones C_Î› such that Î› is a collection of pairwise compatible non-closed allowable curves.  (This statement must be modified if (,) is a marked surface without boundary having exactly one puncture, but we will not need that case here.)

  * The shear coordinates of allowable curves constitute universal geometric coefficients for B(T).

sentence:
Let c be a (k,d)-coloring of a signed graph (G,Ïƒ) in which colors x_0 and its inverse k-x_0 are missing.
Updating c at x_0 is defined as follows: if the color [x_0+d]_k appears in c, then recolor [x_0+d]_k by [x_0+d-1]_k; and meanwhile, if the color [k-x_0-d]_k appears in c, then recolor [k-x_0-d]_k by [k-x_0-d+1]_k. 
Let r be a positive integer.
Updating c at a sequence of colors x_0,[x_0+d]_k,â€¦,[x_0+(r-1)d]_k is called updating c from x_0 by r steps . We also say that a function c' is obtained from c
by updating at x_0 (in r steps) if c' is the final function from V(G) to â„¤_k in this process.

sentence:
Let the height h_J(p) of J at position p (0 â‰¤ p â‰¤ 2k + 1) be
the maximum value of 2k + 1 - a - b where (a, b) âˆˆ J and a - b = 2k + 2 - p.
This is well-defined for all proper, non-empty order ideals J of Q. Let the left height of J be the height of J at position 0, i.e., h_J(0). Let the right height of J be the height of J at position 2k + 1, i.e., h_J(2k+1). 

We say a proper, non-empty order ideal J of Q is balanced if the following holds.


  * h_J(0) < 0,

  * h_J(2k+1) â‰¥ 0,
 
  * |h_J(0)+h_J(2k+1)| = 1.

Note that h_J(0) is odd and h_J(2k+1) is even.

sentence:
Let S be a closed surface and let G^+ and G^- be two graphs embedded in it. We say that (G^+,G^-) is a
normal pair of graphs if G^+ and G^- intersect only in the interior of edges,
each edge of one intersects each edge of the other at most once, and all the intersections are transversal.

sentence:
We say that (G^+,G^-) form a strongly normal pair of graphs if they
are a normal pair of graphs and in addition the intersection of an edge
of G^+ with the interior of a face of G^- has at most one component (and
also with the roles of G^+ and G^- interchanged).

(The path is allowed to â€œgo straightâ€ at some of the vertices, meaning that it keeps walking along the same edge of G^+ or G^-). A well-formed loop is a cycle with the same property except 
(perhaps) at its base vertex.

[ Perfect matchings and weights ]
A perfect matching of a graph G is a subset P of the 
edges of G such that
each vertex of G is incident to exactly one edge of P. 
If the edges of  a perfect matching P of  
G_T^âˆ˜, are labeled Ï„_j_1,â€¦,Ï„_j_r, then 
we define the weight x(P) of P to be 
x_Ï„_j_1â€¦ x_Ï„_j_r.

sentence:
[ Minimal and Maximal Matchings ]  
By induction on the number of tiles it is easy to see that 
G_T^âˆ˜,  
has  precisely two perfect matchings which we call
the minimal matching P_-=P_-(G_T^âˆ˜,) and 
the maximal matching P_+
=P_+(G_T^âˆ˜,), 
which contain only boundary edges.
To distinguish them, 
if  rel(GÌƒ_1,T^âˆ˜)=1 (respectively, -1),
we define 
e_1 and e_2 to be the two edges of 
G_T^âˆ˜, which lie in the counterclockwise 
(respectively, clockwise) direction from 
the diagonal of GÌƒ_1.  Then  P_- is defined as
the unique matching which contains only boundary 
edges and does not contain edges e_1 or e_2.  P_+
is the other matching with only boundary edges.

of G_T^âˆ˜,, P âŠ– P_- encloses the union of tiles âˆª_jâˆˆ J G_i_j.  
We  define the height monomial h(P) of P by

    h(P) = âˆ_k=1^n h_Ï„_k^m_k,

where m_k is the number of tiles in âˆª_jâˆˆ J G_i_j whose

[ Augmentation ]
Fix a bordered surface (S,M), an ideal triangulation T^âˆ˜ of S,
a puncture p, and a loop Ï based at p with a choice of

with a and c incident to p, a and b incident to a marked
point u, and b and c incident to a marked point v.
We then define the
augmented bordered surface (S,M) by
adding a single puncture q to (S,M), placing it inside Î”.
And we construct the
augmented triangulation T^âˆ˜
from T^âˆ˜ by adding three new arcs inside
Î”: an arc Ã¢ from q to u,
an arc Ä‰ from q to v, and an arc bÌ‚ from u to v
(so that bÌ‚ and b form a bigon with the puncture q
inside).    See Figure <ref>.

sentence:
Let L be a (p, q)-leaper with p + q odd, C a cycle of L within a (p + q) Ã— (p + q) chessboard, M the canonical second leaper associated with C, D the canonical second leaper cycle of M over the squares of C, and 4Î¼ the length of both C and D.

Impose orientations on C and D. Given a square a of D, let the arc from a in C point to b and the D-displacement of a be the number of steps along D that lead from a to b.

Then the multiset of all D-displacements consists of all integers between Î¼ and 3Î¼ congruent to Î± modulo four, each occurring precisely eight times, where Î± = 1 or Î± = 3 depending on the orientations of C and D.

sentence:
Let n be a positive integer and L a skew (p, q)-leaper with p < q. Then the leaper graph of L over W_n(L) is trivial and the direction graph extracted from it depends only on n. We refer to this direction graph as the pinwheel direction graph W_n of order n.

(The above continues to apply to non-skew leapers L in the sense that the leaper graph of L over W_n(L) is an instantiation of W_n.)

The pinwheel direction graph of order n is a dual direction graph of complement Ï€_Pinwheel(W_n) when n is odd, where 
    Ï€_Pinwheel = ([        ;         ])
 is the equivalence permutation induced by the unit 2 Ã— 2 matrix and ( [  0  1; -1  0 ]), and Ï€_Reflectâˆ˜Ï€_Pinwheel(W_n) when n is even, and duality matrix A^Pinwheel_n.

We refer to this direction graph as the expanded pinwheel direction graph W_n, d of order n and margin d. It is a dual direction graph of complement Ï€_Pinwheel(W_n, d) when n is odd and Ï€_Reflectâˆ˜Ï€_Pinwheel(W_n, d) when n is even, and duality matrix A^Pinwheel_n.

sentence: A regular chessboard is a rectangular grid of unit squares. A generalized chessboard is a set of unit squares in the plane, with sides parallel to the coordinate axes, obtained from each other by means of integer translations.

sentence: Let p and q be nonnegative integers, at least one of them positive. A (p, q)-leaper L is a fairy chess piece that, from a square a, can move to any of the squares a + (Â± p, Â± q) or a + (Â± q, Â± p).

sentence: The leaper graph of a leaper L over a board B is the graph whose vertices are the squares of B and whose edges join the pairs of squares of B that are joined by a move of L.

sentence: A leaper L is free over a board B if the leaper graph of L over B is connected.

sentence: An open tour of a leaper L over a board B is a Hamiltonian path in the leaper graph of L over B. A closed tour of L over B is a Hamiltonian cycle in the leaper graph of L over B.

sentence: A (p, q)-leaper L is orthogonal if p = 0 or q = 0, diagonal if p = q, and skew if p â‰  0, q â‰  0, and p â‰  q.

sentence: A (p, q)-leaper L is basic if p + q is odd and p and q are relatively prime.

Let F be an (m, n)-frame, m < n, and H an (m, 2m + n)-frame. Place F and H so that their centers coincide. (Or, equivalently, so that the outer contour of F coincides with the inner contour of H.) We define the transformation f, lifting F to H, as follows.

An f-translation is any of the eight translations corresponding to a move of a (0, m + n)-leaper or an (m, m)-leaper. Given a direction i, we write v^f_i for the f-translation pointing in direction i. For instance, v^f_ = (m + n, 0) and v^f_ = (m, m).

Let S be a subset of the squares of F. Then f(S) is a subset of the squares of H, the disjoint union of 
    (S + v^f_i) âˆ© H_i
 when i ranges over , , â€¦, .

sentence:
Let m < n, 3m â‰¥ n, and F be an (m, n)-frame. The shell of F, F^-, is the union of eight equal, symmetrically placed square subboards of F defined as follows.

When 2m â‰¥ n, F^- is the union of eight subboards of F of size (n - m) Ã— (n - m), one in each corner and four adjacent by side to the central hole, as in Figure <ref>.

When 2m â‰¤ n â‰¤ 3m, F^- is the union of eight subboards of F of size (3m - n) Ã— (3m - n), one in the middle of each outer side and four adjacent by corner to the central hole, as in Figure <ref>.

In both cases, the core of F, F^+, is F âˆ– F^-.

sentence: A simple oriented cycle C of a skew leaper is trivial if the sum of the associated direction matrices over C is the zero matrix, and nontrivial otherwise. A simple cycle C of a skew leaper is trivial if any (or, equivalently, both) of its two orientations are, and nontrivial otherwise.

sentence: Let Î¦ be a direction graph and L a leaper. sentence:
A cycle D of a leaper M is (p, q)-perfect , p < q, if it admits a perfect partitioning into eight disjoint nonempty paths, 
    D = a^a^â€¦ a^,
 satisfying the following conditions.

Translation. 
    a^a^ + (-q, -p)    = -a^-a^
     a^a^ + (-p, -q)    = -a^-a^
     a^a^ + (p, -q)    = -a^-a^
     a^a^ + (q, -p)    = -a^-a^


Symmetry. For all directions i out of , , â€¦, , a^i is of odd length, a^i_Mid lies on the ray Î±^i, and a^i is symmetric with respect to Î±^i. Furthermore, a 90^âˆ˜ rotation about O maps a^i onto a^i + 2.

Separation. For all directions i out of , , â€¦, , the counterclockwise portion (a^i_Mid; a^i + 1_Mid) of D lies strictly inside the 45^âˆ˜ angle between the rays Î±^i and Î±^i + 1.

Simplicity. The broken line Îº(D) is the contour of a simple polygon. In particular, D is a simple cycle.

Coherence. D is the leaper graph of M over the squares of D.

A graph G is called a generalized triangle factor if
		every connected component of G is a subgraph of a triangle, i.e.,
		a triangle, a path of length 2, an edge, or a vertex.

Let  denote an ordered field with positive cone Î  and suppose P_1,P_2âˆˆÎ [z] are monic, palindromic polynomials.  Denote by  the -subalgebra of  generated by the coefficients of P_1 and P_2.  Write (P_1,P_2) for the associated generalized cluster algebra over .
   
    
  * For each (a_1,a_2)âˆˆ^2 there exists a (unique) greedy element x[a_1,a_2]âˆˆ(P_1,P_2).

  * The greedy elements x[a_1,a_2] for (a_1,a_2)âˆˆ^2 form a -basis of the generalized cluster algebra (P_1,P_2), which we call the greedy basis .
    
  * The greedy basis is independent of the choice of initial cluster.
    
  * The greedy basis contains all cluster monomials.

Let { x_1, x_2, â€¦, x_n } be a set of Boolean variables. A 2-Xor expression is a finite
conjunction of clauses l âŠ• l', where l and l' are literals, i.e. they are elements of
{x_1, x_2, â€¦, x_n, xÌ…_1, xÌ…_2,â€¦, xÌ…_n}. 

The clauses as well as the literals within each clause are ordered (i.e. for instance that the
clauses xâŠ• y and y âŠ• x are distinct). 
From a combinatorial point of view, an expression can be regarded as a
sequence of clauses where each clause is a pair of two literals. 
Neither the literals of a clause nor the clauses themselves need to be distinct. 

The set of all such expressions is denoted by â„°_n.

sentence:
Let Ïƒ be any filling of a Young diagram with letters from a totally ordered alphabet A, allowing repeated letters.  A relative inversion of a filling Ïƒ of a Young diagram is a pair of entries u and v in the same row, with u to the left of v, such that if b is the entry directly below u, one of the following conditions is satisfied:
   
     
  * u<v and b is between u and v in size, in particular uâ‰¤ b<v.
     
  * u>v and b is not between u and v in size, in particular either b<v<u or v<uâ‰¤ b,
   
   If u and v are on the bottom row, we treat b as any value less than min(u,v), usually 0 in the case A=_+.

Given a word w=w_1â‹¯ w_n of positive integers, a Knuth move consists of either:

sentence:
Let G be a graph containing a path P = v_1 â‹¯ v_r such that âˆ€ i = 1, â€¦, r: _G(v_i) = 2.
	We add a double ear to P by the following construction:
	
		
  *  Connect the first and the last vertex of P by a new edge.
		
  *  Duplicate each edge of P.
	
	Also the path v_1 without edges is allowed as a choice of P. In this case, a loop is added to v_1.
	Observe that all edges added in the above two steps build a cycle. In particular: If G is an Eulerian graph, also the graph obtained by adding a double ear is an Eulerian graph.

	A graph G' that is obtained by replacing an edge with endnodes u and w of a graph G by a new path uvw is called a simple subdivision of G.
	We say that G is obtained from G' by resolving the node v.
	Moreover, Gâ€ is called a subdivision of G if there is a finite sequence (G_0 = G, G_1, G_2, â€¦, G_k = Gâ€) such that G_i is a simple subdivision of G_i-1 for each i = 1, â€¦, k.

[Adding a Double Ear]
	
	Let G be a graph containing a path P = v_1 â‹¯ v_r such that âˆ€ i = 1, â€¦, r: _G(v_i) = 2.
	We add a double ear to P by the following construction:
	
		
  *  Connect the first and the last vertex of P by a new edge.
		
  *  Duplicate each edge of P.
	
	Also the path v_1 without edges is allowed as a choice of P. In this case, a loop is added to v_1.
	Observe that all edges added in the above two steps build a cycle. In particular: If G is an Eulerian graph, also the graph obtained by adding a double ear is an Eulerian graph.

sentence:
Let (G_0, G_1, â€¦, G_k) be a finite sequence of graphs such that for each i = 1, â€¦, k: either
	
		
  * double ear step: G_i is either built by adding a double ear to G_i-1 or
		
  * subdivision step: G_i is a simple subdivision of G_i-1.
	
	Then, we call (G_0, G_1, â€¦, G_k) a double ear decomposition of G_k starting with G_0.
	If G_0 is a cycle, we call G_k a double ear decomposable graph .

sentence:
[Tree Decomposition, Treewidth, Bags, <cit.>]
	A tree decomposition of a graph G = (V, E) is a pair ({X_i i âˆˆ I}, T=(I,F)) with {X_i i âˆˆ I} a family of subsets of V, one for each node of T, and T a tree such that
	
		
  * â‹ƒ_i âˆˆ I X_i = V.
		
  * For all edges vw âˆˆ E, there exists an i âˆˆ I with v âˆˆ X_i and w âˆˆ X_i.
		
  * For all i,j,k âˆˆ I: If j is on the path from i to k in T, then X_i âˆ© X_k âŠ† X_j.
	
	For i âˆˆ I, X_i is called a bag of the tree decomposition.
	The width of a tree decomposition ({X_i i âˆˆ I}, T=(I,F)) is max_i âˆˆ I |X_i|-1.
	The treewidth of a graph G is the minimum width over all possible tree decompositions of G.

sentence: A graph G=(V,E) is a graph of two parallel paths specified by V_1 and V_2 if Gâ‰„P_n, and if V can be partitioned into nonempty sets V_1 and V_2 such that P_1:=G[V_1] and P_2:=G[V_2] are paths, and such that G can be drawn in the plane in such a way that P_1 and P_2 are parallel line segments, and the edges between P_1 and P_2 (drawn as straight line segments) do not cross; such a drawing of G is called a standard drawing . In a standard drawing of G, fix an ordering of the vertices of P_1 and P_2 that is increasing in the same direction for both paths. In this ordering, let first(P_i) and last(P_i) respectively denote the first and last vertices of P_i for i=1,2. The sets {first(P_1),first(P_2)} and {last(P_1),last(P_2)} will be referred to as ends of G.

Let H and G be graphs.
	G is H-saturated
		if G contains no copy of H
		and for every edge e âˆˆ E(G)

	G is uniquely H-saturated
		if G contains no copy of H
		and for every edge e âˆˆ E(G),
		there is a unique copy of H in G + e.

sentence:
Given a SSYT, T, of shape Î» /Î¼ we perform a forward-(jdt)-slide as follows:


  * Choose an inner corner of Î¼, C=(i,j).

  * Let c=min{T(i+1, j), T(i, j+1)} or c=T(i+1, j) if T(i+1, j) = T(i, j+1)  or if only one of T(i+1, j), T(i, j+1) exists then that is taken to be the minimum value. Let C' be the position c is in.

  * Form T' by setting T(i,j)=c and letting C' be empty.

  * Set C:=C' and return to the second step until T' is a SSYT.


Given a SSYT, T, of shape Î» /Î¼ we perform a backward-(jdt)-slide as follows:


  * Choose an outer corner of Î», D=(i,j).

  * Let d=max{T(i-1, j), T(i, j-1)} or d=T(i-1, j) if T(i-1, j) = T(i, j-1)  or if only one of T(i-1, j), T(i, j-1) exists then that is taken to be the maximum value. Let D' be the position d is in.

  * Form Tâ€ by setting T(i,j)=d and letting D' be empty.

  * Set D:=D' and return to the second step until Tâ€ is a SSYT.

sentence: Given two strings of k integers, A = a_0 a_1 â€¦ a_k-1 and B = b_0 b_1 â€¦ b_k-1, we say that A and B are encoding equivalent if a_i â‰¡ b_i 2^k-i-1 for each integer 0â‰¤ iâ‰¤ k-1.  Clearly encoding equivalence is an equivalence relation.  Let the canonical representative of each equivalence class be the member C = c_0 c_1 â€¦ c_k-1 with 0 â‰¤ c_i< 2^k-i-1.  Notice that C is the only member of [C] which is itself the encoding of a graph.  If A is a string, we let C(A) denote the graph encoded by the canonical representative from A's equivalence class.

[The Cathedral Construction] 
Let G_0 be a saturated elementary graph 
and let {G_S}_SâˆˆG_0 be a family of saturated graphs, 
some of which might be empty. 
For each Sâˆˆð’«(G_0), 
join every vertex in S and every vertex of G_S.
We call this operation the cathedral construction . 
Here G_0 and {G_S}_SâˆˆG_0 
are respectively called  
the foundation and the family of towers .

sentence: Let i â‰¥ 1 be an index and T a semistandard shifted tableau.  A pair of entries y,x of T, with y âˆˆ{i+1,i+1} and x âˆˆ{i,i} are i-paired if y occurs before x in the hook reading word of T and every entry i, i, i+1, i+1 that lies between them in the hook reading word is i-blocked. The i-paired entries become i-blocked, and we continue the operation recursively till there are no more possible i-pairs. An entry i,i,i+1,i+1 of T is i-free if it is not part of an i-pair.

Let T be an injective Young tableau, and let x be a positive integer not occurring in T. Let T_i be the ith lowest row of T. Define the insertion of x into T , denoted by T xâ†, as follows. Set x_0=x and for iâ‰¥ 0, insert x_i into T_i+1, set x_i+1 to be the bumped letter, and
  
  
  * if x_i+1 is nonempty, continue;
  
  * otherwise, if no letter is bumped, stop.
  
  The insertion tableau of a permutation w, denoted by P(w), is the standard Young tableau obtained by beginning with the empty tableau and successively inserting the letters of w.
  
  The recording tableau of w, denoted by Q(w), is the standard Young tableau with entry i in the unique cell of P_i / P_i-1, where (âˆ… = P_0,P_1,â€¦,P_n = P(w)) is the sequence of tableaux created when inserting w.

sentence: A lie restriction R is a condition on binary strings.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O

sentence:
The Renyi-Ulam game with lie restriction R is played as follows.

There are two players: the Seeker and the Obscurer. The Obscurer thinks of a number between 1 and n. The Seeker wishes to identify that number.

On each turn, the Seeker asks the Obscurer whether her number belongs to a specific subset of the numbers from 1 to n. The Obscurer answers either yes or no, and her answer is either true or false. On every turn, the series of truths and lies given by the Obscurer thus far must belong to R.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O
plain_text_term: Renyi-Ulam game with lie restriction R

sentence:
A lie restriction graph G for a lie restriction R is a directed graph G such that:



  * One vertex in G is called a start vertex .

  * Every arc in G is labeled either 0 or 1.

  * Every vertex in G originates at least one and at most two outward arcs. Of those, at most one arc is labeled 0 and at most one arc is labeled 1.

  * A binary string s satisfies R if and only if there is a path l in G such that l starts from the start vertex and the arc labels along l trace out s.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A position is a mapping from the vertices of G to the nonnegative integers.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: The support of a position P is the number of vertices v of G such that P(v) is nonzero.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: The weight of a position P is the sum of P(v) over all vertices v of G.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let P, P_1, and P_2 be three positions. We say that (P_1, P_2) is a split of P if there exist two positions Q_0 and Q_1 such that



  * For all vertices v of G, P(v) = Q_0(v) + Q_1(v).

  * For all vertices v of G, P_1(v) is the sum of Q_0(u) over all vertices u of G such that a 0-arc in G points from u to v.

  * For all vertices v of G, P_2(v) is the sum of Q_1(u) over all vertices u of G such that a 1-arc in G points from u to v.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A strategy-like tree is a binary tree such that its vertices are positions and every non-leaf vertex P has two children that form a split of P. A strategy-like tree for a position P is a strategy-like tree rooted at P.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A strategy tree is a strategy-like tree whose every leaf has weight either zero or one. A strategy tree for a position P is a strategy tree rooted at P.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A lie restriction R is regular if the set of all strings that satisfy R is a regular language.
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: The two-string game for a lie restriction R is played between two players as follows. The starting position is given by two binary strings u_1 and u_2. On each turn, the Obscurer extends one of u_1 and u_2 (that is, appends a character to it) and the Seeker replies by extending the other. The Seeker's goal is that one of the two strings ceases to satisfy R (it does not matter whether this happens following a move by the Seeker or the Obscurer) and the Obscurer's goal is to prevent this.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: We say that S_1 is expanded by S_2 if S_1 contains a substring of every string in S_2.
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: The risk of a string p is the length of the longest suffix of p that is a prefix of an element of S. When p is of risk l and the l-suffix of p is an l-prefix of q âˆˆ S, we say that p is of risk l via q. The risk of a position P in the two-string game for R is the maximum of the risks of the two strings that comprise P.

sentence: The l-flip of a string p = a_1a_2 â€¦ a_m of length m â‰¥ l + 1 is the string a_1a_2 â€¦ a_la_l + 1.

Let G = (V,E) be a graph with a total order on E, and F be a maximal spanning forest of G.  We say that an edge e âˆˆ E is spanning forest


  * internally active (e âˆˆI(F)) with respect to F if eâˆˆ F and it is the smallest edge in U_F(e),

  * externally active (e âˆˆE(F)) with respect to F if eâˆ‰F and it is the smallest edge in Z_F(e).




We note that all bridges are internally active and all loops are externally active.

sentence: Let Ã˜ be an orientation of the edges of G.  Let Z be a cycle in G, and U = (X,X^c) be a cut in G.  We say that Z is a directed cycle if we can walk around the cycle traveling in the direction of the edge orientations.  We similarly define U to be a directed cut if all of its edges are, without loss of generality, oriented from X to X^c.

Let G be a graph and let X âŠ‚ V(G) satisfy |X| =k â‰¥ 2. We say G[X] is a chain of sausages of order k in G if 

G. (V(G)âˆ– X ) is a doubled cycle (of length k+1).  
If G[X] is a chain of sausages of order at least 3 and x,x' âˆˆ X are adjacent, then the operation of identifying x and x' to a new vertex is called a sausage shortening .  If G' is obtained from G by repeatedly performing sausage shortenings until this operation is no longer possible, we call G' a sausage reduction of G.  We say that G is sausage reduced if it has no sausage of order at least 3 (so no sausage reduction is possible).

sentence: A 2-coloring on n vertices is a set of n vertices between every two of which is either a red or a blue edge. Additionally, the 2-coloring is said to be ordered if every vertex has a unique integer from 1 to n assigned to it, indicating the order-label of the vertex.

sentence:
Given an ordered 2-coloring G and a k-ordering H, we say that G contains H if there exists a copy of H in G that satisfies the following properties:


  * The edges in the copy of H are all the same color. (monochromatic)


  * The ith smallest-labeled vertex in the copy of H either has order-label i in H or no order-label in H. (order-preserving)

sentence: Given an ordered 2-coloring G and a k-coloring H, we say that G avoids H if G does not contain H.

sentence: The ordered Ramsey number R_<(H_1,H_2) of a k-ordering H_1 and a j-ordering H_2 is the smallest number n such that any ordered 2-coloring on n vertices must contain a red copy of H_1 or a blue copy of H_2. As a shorthand, R_<(H, H) is denoted by R_<(H).

An ordered graph G_< is called a semi-comparability graph , if it has no 4 vertices a,b,c,dâˆˆ V(G_<) such that a<b<c<d and ab,bc,cdâˆˆ E(G_<), but ac,bdâˆ‰E(G_<).

An unordered graph G is said to be a semi-comparability graph, if its vertex set has a total ordering < such that G_< is a semi-comparability graph.

sentence:
A double-ordered graph G_<_1,<_2 is called magical if for any three distinct vertices a,b,câˆˆ V(G) with a<_1b<_1c, if ab,bcâˆˆ E(G) and acâˆ‰E(G), then b<_2a and b<_2c.

A graph G is said to be magical, if there exist two total orders <_1,<_2 on V(G) such that G_<_1,<_2 is magical. In this case, we say that the pair (<_1,<_2) witnesses G.

sentence: A triple-ordered graph G_<_1,<_2,<_3 is called double-magical , if there exist two magical graphs G^1_<_1,<_2 and G^2_<_1,<_3 on V(G)  such that  E(G_<_1,<_2,<_3)=E(G^1_<_1,<_2)âˆ© E(G^2_<_1,<_3). An unordered graph G is said to be double-magical, if there exist three total orders <_1,<_2,<_3 on V(G) such that the triple-ordered graph G_<_1,<_2,<_3 is double-magical. We say that G is witnessed by (<_1,<_2,<_3).

sentence:
An oriented Young graph is the graph that is obtained from a Young diagram after rotating it in 180 degrees and orienting each horizontal edge from left to right and each vertical edge from bottom to top.
We call the vertex that is in the lower right corner the origin vertex , and denote the upper right
(lower left) vertex by v_1 (v_0). There are two paths that start at v_0, continue along the border and end at
v_1. The path that passes through the origin vertex is called inner path , and the second path is called
outer path . From now on, we denote the set of the vertices appear in the outer path by V.
See FigureÂ <ref> for an example.


    < g r a p h i c s >

An oriented Young graph. Its inner boundary path is formed by the edges labeled from 1' through 7'.
Its outer boundary path is formed by the edges labeled from 1 through 7, and all the vertices that appear along the latter path form the collection V.

sentence:
[<cit.>]
Let T be a genomic tableau with entries i_j. We call i the gene family and j the gene . First, we say T is semistandard if:


  * The tableau T_ss obtained by forgetting the genes is semistandard (that is, each gene family forms a horizontal strip);

  * Within each gene family, the genes form a Pieri strip.

We say the K-theoretic content of T is (c_1, â€¦, c_r) if c_i is the max-content of the Pieri strip of genes in the i-th gene family. Finally, we say T is ballot if it is semistandard and has the following property:


  (*) Let T' be any genomic tableau obtained by deleting, within each gene family of T, all but one of every repeated gene. Let T'_ss be the tableau obtained by deleting the corresponding entries of T_ss. Then the reading word of T'_ss is ballot.

Let Q, Q' be quivers with the same vertex set Q_0 = Q_0'. 


  * Two potentials W and W' on Q are cyclically equivalent if W-W' lies in the closure of the vector subspace of R âŸ¨âŸ¨ Q âŸ©âŸ© spanned by all the elements of the form Î±_1 â€¦Î±_l - Î±_2 â€¦Î±_l Î±_1 with Î±_1 â€¦Î±_l a cycle of positive length.


  * We say that two QPs (Q,W) and (Q',W') are right-equivalent if there exists a â„‚-algebra isomorphism Ï• : R âŸ¨âŸ¨ Q âŸ©âŸ©â†’ R âŸ¨âŸ¨ Q' âŸ©âŸ© satisfying Ï•(e_i) = e_i âˆ€ i âˆˆ Q_0 = Q_0' and such that Ï•(W) is cyclically-equivalent to W'.


  * For each arrow Î±âˆˆ Q_1 and each cycle Î±_1 â€¦Î±_l in Q we define the cyclic derivative 
    âˆ‚_Î±(Î±_1 â€¦Î±_l) = âˆ‘_k=1^lÎ´_Î±,Î±_kÎ±_k+1â‹¯Î±_l  Î±_1 â‹¯Î±_k-1
 and extend âˆ‚_Î± by linearity and continuity so that âˆ‚_Î±(W) is defined for every potential W.


  * The Jacobian ideal J(W) is the topological closure of the two-sided ideal of R âŸ¨âŸ¨ Q âŸ©âŸ© generated by {âˆ‚_Î±(W) | Î±âˆˆ Q_1 }, and the Jacobian algebra P(Q,W) is the quotient algebra R âŸ¨âŸ¨ Q âŸ©âŸ© / J(W).


  * A QP is trivial if W âˆˆ A^2 and {âˆ‚_Î±(W) | Î±âˆˆ Q_1 } spans A as a â„‚-vector space.


  * A QP is reduced if the degree-2 component of W is 0, that is, if the expression of W involves no 2-cycles.


  * The direct sum Q âŠ• Q' is the quiver whose vertex set is Q_0 = Q_0' and whose arrow set is the disjoint union Q_1 âŠ” Q_1'.


  * The direct sum of two QPs (Q,W) and (Q',W') is the QP (Q,W) âŠ• (Q',W') = (Q âŠ• Q', W+W').

  Series-parallel graphs are graphs that arise from a forest by

  * add a parallel edge to an existing edge and subdivide this new edge
    (this is the parallel extension );
  
  * subdivide an edge (this is the series extension ).

  * A finite graded lattice is Eulerian if
		any non-trivial interval has the same number of elements of odd and of even rank;
		it is interval-connected if the proper part of any interval of length at leastÂ 3 is connected.
		
  * A CW-sphere is regular if the attaching maps of the cells are homeomorphisms also
		on the boundary. The sphere has the intersection property if 
		the intersection of any two cells is a single cell (which may be empty).

sentence:
Components of type T_3,T_4 or T_5,1 that are contained in a white face, and components of type T_3,T_4,T_5,2, as well as pairs of triangles of type T_3,1 contained in a black face, are called exceptional components .
Consider Gâˆˆ P_m, and let f_1,f_2 be two faces of the same color, such that f_1 has at least two boundary components.
By choosing f_1 to be the outer face, we may think of G as a planar graph.


 
    < g r a p h i c s >

 These are the 7 types of exceptional components. They are the components that contribute to the automorphism terms, and that receive special treatment in the flattening process



If f_2 does not belong to an exceptional component, we define a flattening from f_2 to f_1 as the operation of taking all of the connected components of G surrounded by f_2, and moving them, together with the parts of G in the planar region they bound, to the interior of f_1. If f_2 is exceptional, all of the connected components of G surrounded by f_2, except for one component, are moved to f_1, together with the parts of G in the planar region they bound. If f_2 surrounds several components, not all of whom are triangles, then one of the non-triangular components remains in f_2. In particular, if f_2 is a white triangle that surrounds a black triangle as well as a non-triangular component, then we leave a non-triangular component in f_2.

If f_2 is a white triangle and also a connected component of size three that surrounds more than one component, all of whom are triangles, then we view f_2 together with one of the triangles it surrounds as a component of type T_3,1. In this case, we move all but two of the triangles f_2 surrounds to f_1.




We say that a graph G âˆˆ P_m is flat if G has a white face f_w and a black face f_b such that


  * The faces of G surround at most two components, except possibly f_w and f_b.

  * If f âˆ‰{f_b,f_w} is a face of G that surrounds two components, then f is a white triangle surrounding two black triangles.

  * The remaining faces that surround a component belong to exceptional components.

  * A mosaic
is a rooted graph (H,x)

(H[V'],x) is an unbristled mosaic,
and  E(H)-E(H[V']) is a perfect matching between
Vâ€ and a subset ofÂ V'.
The edges of the matching are called bristles .

  * A proper mosaic is a
mosaic that contains at least one cycle.

Let P=x_1â€¦ x_â„“+1 be a path in a graphÂ H.  We define the
following three sets of (â„“+2)-walks from x_1 to x_â„“+1.



  * T_1(P) is the set of walks that differ fromÂ P by going the
  long way around a (2r+2)-cycle from which P uses rÂ consecutive
  edges, as shown in FigureÂ <ref>.  Formally, these
  are the walks x_1â€¦ x_aP'x_bâ€¦ x_â„“+1, where 1â‰¤
  a<bâ‰¤â„“+1 and x_aP'x_b is a (b-a+2)-path in H-{x_a+1,
  â€¦, x_b-1}.

  * T_2(P) is the set of walks that differ fromÂ P by going the
  long way around cycles of length 2r+1 and 2r'+1, from which
  PÂ uses r andÂ r' consecutive edges, respectively, as shown in
  FigureÂ <ref>.  Formally, these are the x_1â€¦
  x_aP'x_bâ€¦ x_a'Pâ€x_b'â€¦ x_â„“+1 where 1â‰¤ a<bâ‰¤
  a'<b'â‰¤â„“+1, x_aP'x_b is a (b-a+1)-path in H-{x_a+1,
  â€¦, x_b-1} and x_a'Pâ€x_b' is a (b'-a'+1)-path in
  H-{x_a'+1, â€¦, x_b'-1}.

  * T_3(P) is the set of walks x_1â€¦ x_azx_aâ€¦ x_â„“+1,
  where 1â‰¤ aâ‰¤{â„“+1} and zâˆˆÎ“_H(x_a) (we allow the
  case z=x_aÂ± 1).


We refer to the cycles appearing in the definition of T_1 andÂ T_2
as detour cycles .

sentence:

  T_0^L corresponding to T_0 is the infinite (from right to left) product

    T_0^L=â‹¯  s^3(T_0) s^2(T_0) s(T_0) T_0.

It is clear that this product converges to a lower triangular matrix.
Similarly, the right iterated matrix

In this case T_0 is called a fundamental sequence
of the Gaussian elimination process of A.

sentence:
[Kostochka et al.Â <cit.>]

Consider an n-vertex (d+1)-uniform hypergraph H such that every d-tuple of vertices is contained in at most t=O(1) edges,
and apply the following procedure:


  * let X be the subset of vertices obtained by choosing each vertex independently at random with probability p, such that
pn = ( n/(t logloglog n) )^3/(3d-1),

  * remove the minimum number of vertices of X so that the resulting subset Y induces a triangle-free linear[A hypergraph is linear if it has no pair of distinct edges sharing two or more vertices.] hypergraph H[Y].

Then with high probability H[Y] has an independent set of size at least ( n/tlogn/t)^1/d.

sentence:
In a fixed border-strip decomposition, a border-strip B_a is above a border-strip B_b if there is 
a path from B_a to B_b going only down or right. In this case B_b is below B_a.

sentence:
A border-strip B_a is inner to a border-strip B_b if there exists a sequence B_a=B_1,B_2,â€¦,B_k=B_b such that for all i B_i is above B_i+1. This means the relation inner is the transitive closure of the relation above .

If B_a is inner to B_b, B_b is outer to B_a.

Two border strips B_a and B_b are comparable , if B_a is inner or outer to B_b.

sentence:
Two border strips B_1 and B_2 in a decomposition 
form an inversion if the following three conditions are fulfilled:

 
  * The content-sequences of B_1 and B_2 have a non-empty intersection,
 
  * B_1 is inner to B_2, and
 
  * B_1>B_2.

Let M be a monoid.
AÂ subset M'âŠ‚ M is called potentially invertible
if M can be embedded into a larger monoid in which all elements ofÂ M'
have left and right inverses (necessarily equal to each other);
see <cit.>.
Similarly, a subsetÂ R' of a ringÂ R is potentially invertible
if R can be embedded into a larger ring in which all elements of R' are invertible.

By abuse of terminology, we say
that elements g_1,â€¦,g_N
of a monoid (or ring) are potentially
invertible if {g_1,â€¦,g_N} is a potentially invertible subset.

sentence:
Throughout the paper by an infinite surface  we mean a connected oriented surface  


  - of a finite genus,

  - with finitely many interior marked points (punctures),

  - with finitely many boundary components, 

  - with infinitely many boundary marked points, located in such a way that they have only finitely many accumulation points of boundary marked points.  
 
 Accumulation points themselves are also considered as boundary marked points.

sentence:
By an admissible hyperbolic structure on an infinite surface  
we mean a locally hyperbolic metric such that
 

  - all boundary arcs are complete (i.e. bi-infinite) geodesics, and

  - all interior marked points are  cusps.


A surface with admissible hyperbolic structure will be called an admissible hyperbolic surface.

A simplicial poset is a conditionally complete poset where every cone is

The cones of a simplicial complex K are thus called its simplices.
Clearly, every simplicial complex is atomic.

sentence:
If P=(ð’«,â‰¤) is a [pre]poset and
a,bâˆˆð’« are such that aâ‰¤ b, the interval [a,b] is

If P is a poset, we define the canonical subdivision P^# of P to be

In the general case some additional care is needed.
We say that an interval [a,b] is pre-included in an interval [c,d] and
write [a,b]â‹[c,d] if aâˆˆ [c,d] and bâˆˆ [c,d].

of P (the latter set is really just the relation â‰¤ which officially is
a subset of ð’«ð’«).
We define the canonical subdivision P^# of P to be the preposet of
all intervals of P ordered by pre-inclusion.

We note that the canonical subdivision of every poset is an atomic poset.
If P is a conditionally complete poset, then so is P^#.

all preposets P and Q.

Beware that if Q is a full subposet of P, then Q^# need not be full in P^#.

A cubical poset is a conditionally complete poset where every cone is
isomorphic to a cube.
(Compare <cit.>.)
A â€œcubical cone complexâ€ is abbreviated to a cubical complex.
Cones of a cubical complex are thus called its cubes.
Closed subposets of a cubical complex will be termed its subcomplexes.
By the above, the product of two cubical complexes is a cubical complex.
Every cubical complex is atomic, since every cube is.

In contrast to Theorem <ref>, not every cubical complex is isomorphic to
a subcomplex of a cube.
For instance, the simplicial complex âˆ‚Î”^2, which also happens
to be a cubical complex, is not isomorphic to any subcomplex of any cube,
as it contains â€œa cycle of odd lengthâ€.

sentence:
Let X be a poset.
Then [Ïƒ,Ï„]<[Ï,Ï…] in X^# iff Ïâ‰¤Ïƒ and
Ï„â‰¤Ï….
The dual cone [Ïƒ,Ï„] is the poset of all such intervals
[Ï,Ï…]; clearly, it is isomorphic to
(Ïƒ)^*Ï„.
Then every cone [Ïƒ,Ï„]^*=([Ïƒ,Ï„])^*
of the dual poset h(X)(X^#)^* is isomorphic to the product
Ïƒ(Ï„)^*=ÏƒÏ„^*.

The maximal cones of h(X) (i.e. those cones that are not properly contained
in other cones) are of the form [Ïƒ,Ïƒ]^*, where
Ïƒâˆˆ X, and are called the (canonical) handles h_Ïƒ of
the poset X.
Each h_Ïƒ is isomorphic to the product of the cone Ïƒ of
X and the cone Ïƒ^* of X^*.
These cones are called the core and cocore of the handle
h_Ïƒ.

When Ïƒ<Ï„, the intersection h_Ïƒâˆ© h_Ï„ is clearly
the cone [Ïƒ,Ï„]^* of h(X).
However, when Ïƒ and Ï„ are incomparable in X, it may be
that h_Ïƒâˆ© h_Ï„ is nonempty (namely, it is nonempty iff both
Ïƒâˆ©Ï„ and Ïƒâˆ©Ï„ are
nonempty).
This distinguishes the canonical handles from the barycentric ones, which will
be discussed in a moment.

sentence:

is collared in f^-1( q) for each qâˆˆ Q.

sentence:
We say that a closed subposet Q of P is of codimension one in P
if every maximal element of Q is covered by at least one maximal element
of P.
If additionally no maximal element of Q is covered by a non-maximal element of
P, then we say that Q is of pure codimension one in P.

We note that if Q is collared in P, then the link in P of every maximal
element of Q is a singleton; in other words, every maximal element of Q is
covered by precisely one maximal element of P, and by no other element
of P.
On the other hand, if Q is of codimension one in P, then it is nowhere
dense in P, in the sense of the Alexandroff topology (i.e. contains no maximal
element of P).

sentence:
We call a monotone map of posets f Pâ†’ Q a [pure] filtration map if
f^-1(âˆ‚ q) is of [pure] codimension one in f^-1( q)
for each qâˆˆ Q.
Filtration maps (an in particular stratification maps) are open, since
if q>f(p), then f^-1(âˆ‚ q) is contains a maximal element p'
such that p'â‰¥ p, and this p' must be covered by an element of
f^-1( q), which can only be in f^-1(q).

sentence:
Let I denote the 1-simplex.
Given a poset P and a pâˆˆ P, suppose that p is isomorphic to
Q+I for some Q by an isomorphism h such that {p,q,r}:=h^-1(I)
is full in P (in other words, p is the least upper bound of q and r
in P).
In this situation we say that P elementarily zips onto the quotient poset
P/{p,q,r} (see <ref>) along p.
If additionally p^* is collared in q^* and in r^*,
then we say that P elementarily transversely zips onto
P/h^-1(I) along p.
A [transverse] zipping is a sequence of elementary [transverse] zippings.

Non-transverse zipping was introduced by N. Reading <cit.>; the author has been
aware of the notion for a few years before he learned of Reading's paper
from E. Nevo.

In the case that the weight w(x) is distinct for every vertex x, f is called	a D-antimagic labeling of G. In particular, if the set of weights {w(x)| xâˆˆ V(G)} constitutes an arithmetic progression starting at Î± with difference Î´ > 0, then f is called an (Î±,Î´)-D-antimagic labeling of G.

If D={1}, a D-magic (resp. D-antimagic, (Î±,Î´)-D-antimagic) labeling is known as a distance magic (resp. distance antimagic, (Î±,Î´)-distance antimagic) labeling , and if D={0,1}, a D-magic (resp. sentence: A connected graph G of diameter d is called distance-regular if there are non-negative integers b_i, c_i (0â‰¤ i â‰¤ d) such that for any two vertices x and y in G at distance i=d(x,y), there are precisely c_i neighbours of y in G_i-1(x) and b_i neighbours of y in G_i+1(x). Clearly, G is regular with degree r=b_0, b_d=c_0=0, and c_1=1. The sequence i(G)={r,b_1,â€¦,b_d-1;1,c_2,â€¦,c_d} is called the intersection array of G; and the numbers a_i, b_i, and c_i (i=0,â€¦,d), where a_i=r-b_i-c_i, are called the intersection numbers of G.

  * one thickened strips Î˜_j is on the right side or the bottom side of the other thickened strip Î˜_i and they have some special corners in common, where each common special corner (s,t) is a lower corner of Î˜_i and an upper corner of Î˜_j.

sentence:
Consider a g-tuple

    (P(u_Ï€_1,v_1),P(u_Ï€_2,v_2),â€¦, P(u_Ï€_g,v_g))

of double lattice paths where P(u_Ï€_i,v_i)âˆˆP(u_Ï€_i,v_i). Then (<ref>) is non-crossing if for any i and j, P(u_Ï€_i,v_i) and P(u_Ï€_j,v_j) are non-crossing. This holds if and only if


  * P(u_Ï€_i,v_i) and P(u_Ï€_j,v_j) are non-intersecting, that is, have no points in common;

  * P(u_Ï€_j,v_j) is on the top side of P(u_Ï€_i,v_i) and they have some points in common, where each common point (c+1,q) occurs only when one diagonal step of P(u_Ï€_j,v_j) and one horizontal step of P(u_Ï€_i,v_i) end at the same point (c+1,q). 

Otherwise P(u_Ï€_i,v_i) and P(u_Ï€_j,v_j) are crossing and (<ref>) is crossing. If (<ref>) is non-crossing, we call every common point of any two double lattice paths in (<ref>) a touchpoint of (<ref>).

For a g-tuple PÌƒ (see (<ref>)) of double lattice paths, we say that PÌƒ is non-separable at a single point if there exist two double lattice paths in PÌƒ such that they are non-separable at a single point. Otherwise we say that PÌƒ is separable at all single points.

sentence:
Let Î²âˆˆâ„_>1 and let A_Î²={0, 1, â€¦, âŒˆÎ²âŒ‰ -1 }.
Every real number x âˆˆ [0, 1) can be written as a series

    x = âˆ‘_j=1^+âˆž c_j Î²^-j

where c_j âˆˆ A_Î² for all jâ‰¥ 1, and where âŒˆÂ·âŒ‰ denotes the ceiling function defined by âŒˆ x âŒ‰ = inf{ zâˆˆâ„¤| z â‰¥ x }. 
The infinite word c_1 c_2 â‹¯ is called a Î²-representation of x. 
Among all the Î²-representations of x, we define the Î²-expansion d_Î²(x) of x obtained in a greedy way, i.e., for all jâ‰¥ 1, we have  c_j Î²^-j + c_j+1Î²^-j-1 + â‹¯  < Î²^-j+1.
We also make use of the following convention: if w=w_nâ‹¯ w_0 is a finite word (resp., w=w_1 w_2 â‹¯ is an infinite word) over A_Î², the notation 0.w has to be understood as the real number âˆ‘_j=0^n w_j Î²^j-n-1 (resp., âˆ‘_j=1^+âˆž w_j Î²^-j); it actually corresponds to the value of the word w in base Î². 

In an analogous way, the Î²-expansion d_Î²(1) of 1 the following infinite word over A_Î²

    d_Î²(1) := 
    {[                           (Î²-1)^Ï‰,                               Î²âˆˆâ„•;; ( âŒˆÎ²âŒ‰ -1 ) d_Î² ( 1 - (âŒˆÎ²âŒ‰ -1)/ Î²),                                    ].
 
In other words, if Î² is not an integer, the first digit of the Î²-expansion of 1 is âŒˆÎ²âŒ‰ -1 and the other digits are derived from the Î²-expansion of 1 - (âŒˆÎ²âŒ‰ -1)/ Î².

Let d_Î² (1) = (t_n )_nâ‰¥ 1 be the Î²-expansion of 1. 
Observe that t_1 = âŒˆÎ²âŒ‰ -1. 
We define the quasi-greedy Î²-expansion d_Î²^*(1) of 1 as follows.

sentence:
Let U = (U(n))_nâ‰¥ 0 be a sequence of integers such that U is increasing, U(0)=1 and sup_n â‰¥ 0U(n+1)/U(n) is bounded by a constant. 
We say that U is a linear numeration system if U satisfies a linear recurrence relation, i.e., there exist kâ‰¥ 1 and a_0, â€¦, a_k-1âˆˆâ„¤ such that

    âˆ€ n â‰¥ 0,    U(n+k) = a_k-1  U(n+k-1) + â‹¯ + a_0  U(n)
     .

Let n be a positive integer. 
By successive Euclidean divisions, there exists â„“â‰¥ 1 such that 

    n = âˆ‘_j=0^â„“ -1 c_j  U(j)

where the c_j's are non-negative integers and c_â„“-1 is non-zero. 
The word c_â„“ -1â‹¯ c_0 is called the normal U-representation of n and is denoted by _U(n). 
In other words, the word c_â„“-1â‹¯ c_0 is the greedy expansion of n in the considered numeration system. 
We set _U(0):=Îµ. 
Finally, we refer to L_U:=_U(â„•) as the language of the numeration and we let A_U denote the minimal alphabet such that L_U âŠ‚ A_U^*.  
If d_râ‹¯ d_0 is a word over an alphabet of digits, then its U-numerical value is

Observe that, if _U (d_râ‹¯ d_0) = n, then the word d_r â‹¯ d_0 is a
U-representation of n (but not necessarily its normal U-representation).

Here are some basic definitions.


  * A color c's index positions with a tuple S_i(r,k) are the set of its positions within that tuple.

  * The tuples S_i(r,k) are sometimes called a block .

  * The acronym k-TMAP is short for a k-term monochromatic arithmetic progression.

  * If x_1,x_2,â€¦,x_k is an arithmetic progression, then the common value x_i+1-x_i is called the common difference .

  * For a fixed k and r, a valid r-coloring of {1,2,3,â€¦,n} is one which contains no k-TMAP.

sentence:
Let X be a mixed cycle of order n. Then, X is switching equivalent to exactly one of the three following mixed cycles:
	
		
  1. C_n: The mixed cycle whose all edges are undirected.
		
  2.  C_n^1: The mixed cycle which has exactly one directed edge.
		
  3.  C_n^2: The mixed cycle which has two consecutive directed edges with the same direction and all its other edges are undirected.
	
	We call them mixed cycles of Type 0, 1 and 2, respectively.

sentence: We call a graph unicyclic if it contains exactly one cycle.

We call a graph pseudotree if it is a tree or a unicyclic graph.
  Equivalently, pseudotrees are graphs with at most one cycle.

sentence:
A corolla graph is a unicyclic graph obtained by taking a cycle graph
  and joining some path graphs to it by identifying their endpoints with some vertex of that cycle.
  Every path is joined to exactly one vertex of the cycle. And every vertex
  of the cycle has at most one path attached.

However, we shall abuse notation and use the multi-set Q as a metonym for the entire coset progression.] Q of an additive group G of the form

For any subgroup H of G and for any integer d, we say that P is a polynomial of degree <d along H according to the following recursive definition[Our conventions here are somewhat nonstandard, but are chosen so that the proofs of our main theorems, such as Theorem <ref>, resemble the proofs of warmup results such as Proposition <ref>.]:


  (i)  If d â‰¤ 0, we say that P is of degree <d along H if and only if it is identically zero.

    P(x+h) = P(x) + P_h(x)

for all x âˆˆ G.

sentence:
A EW-tableau T is a 0/1-filling of a Ferrers diagram with the following properties:


  1. The top row of T has a 1 in every cell.

  2. Every other row has at least one cell containing a 0.

  3. No four cells of T that form the corners of a rectangle have 0s in two diagonally opposite corners and 1s in the other two.

The size of a EW-tableau is its semiperimeter less one, that is, one less than the sum of its numbers of rows and columns. Let (F) be the set of EW-tableaux on the diagram F.

Let T be a EW-tableau of shape F. Let S=S(T) be the supplementary tableau
corresponding to T.  Let us call a pair of cells a and b in a tableau non-attacking if they are in different rows and different columns.  We also say

sentence:
Let G be a signed graph with an edge e={i,j}âˆˆ E(G) with sign Ïƒ(e).
The deletion of G by e, denoted Gâˆ– e, is the signed graph obtained by removing e from E(G).
A contraction of G by e, denoted G/e, is a signed graph in the same switching class as the graph obtained from G by the following process (which is well-defined up to switching equivalence).


  * If Ïƒ(e)=1, then delete e from E(G) and contract as in the ordinary graph case by identifying i and j in V(G).
When {i,j} is also present in E(G) as a negative edge, add a half-edge at the vertex given by i=j after contracting (if this half-edge is not already present).

  * If Ïƒ(e)=-1, then first switch at an endpoint of e so that Ïƒ(e)=1 and proceed as in the positive edge contraction case.


Given a half-edge iâˆˆ E(G), the deletion of G by i, denoted Gâˆ– i, is the signed graph obtained by removing i from E(G).
The contraction of G by i, denoted G/i, is the signed graph with vertex set V(G)âˆ–{i} and edge set {eâˆ–{i}| eâˆˆ E(G)}.

sentence:
A string x is primitive if  x cannot be expressed as a non-trivial power of any string.
For any string x, there is a primitive string y so that x=y^m for some integer mâ‰¥ 1. Such y and m are unique and y is called the primitive root of x.
Two strings x and y are conjugates if there are strings u and v so that x=uv and y=vu. Note that x is a trivial conjugate of
itself. Often the term rotation is used for conjugates.

sentence:
Let r â‰¥ 1 be an integer. A triangulation of the cylinder of height r is a rooted planar map such that all faces are triangles except for two distinguished faces verifying:


  * The boundaries of the two distiguished faces form two disjoint simple cycles.

  * The boundary of one of the two distinguished faces contains the root edge, and this face is on the right hand side of the root edge. We call this face the root face and the other distiguished face the exterior face.

  * Every vertex of the exterior face is at graph distance exactly r from the boundary of the root face, and edges of the boundary of the exterior face also belong to a triangle whose third vertex is at distance r-1 from the root face.

For every intergers r,p,q â‰¥ 1, a triangulation of the (r,p,q)-cylinder is a triangulation of the cylinder of height r such that its root face has degree p and its exterior face has degree q.

  * Ïƒ'_i-1=Ïƒ_i-1 + D-1 (for i â‰  0)

We also say that i is fired.

sentence:
[Skeletons]
  A skeleton is a  tree T that admits a black-red
  coloringÂ Î» of V(T), a sequence T_0,T_1, â€¦, T_t of
  trees, and a sequence P_1, â€¦,P_t of paths, each of which is a 4-path or a 6-path, 
  such that: 
  
  
  * T_0 is a 3-path, T_t = T, and
  for iâˆˆ[t] the tree T_i is obtained from T_i-1 by
  adding P_i so that the joint of P_i is identified
  with a vertex of T_i-1;
   
  * for T_0=x_0x_1x_2x_3, we have Î»(x_0)= Î»(x_3)= black 
  and Î»(x_1)= Î»(x_2)= red;
  
  * for each P_i=x_0â‹¯ x_k, iâˆˆ[t], it holds that
  Î»(x_0)= Î»(x_k)= black, Î»(x_1)= Î»(x_k-1)= red,
  if k=4, then x_k/2= red, 
  and if k=6, then x_k/2= black 
  and Î»(x_2)=Î»(x_4)= red.

sentence:
[Bunch of squares] 
  Let k â‰¥ 1. A bunch B of k squares (or simply, a bunch ) is a graph obtained from the union of k pairwise
  edge-disjoint squares, say Q_1,â€¦,Q_k, such that each of these squares contains
  two non-adjacent vertices a, b,
  and V(Q_i)âˆ© V(Q_j)={a,b} for 1â‰¤ i<jâ‰¤ k.

sentence:
[Hanging-square graphs] 
A graph H is a hanging-square graph if it is the union of a skeleton T_H
and a set â„¬ of maximal bunches so that the following holds.


  (i) For each B âˆˆâ„¬, at least one joint of B is identified with vertices of T_H;
accordingly, if only one joint is identified, then
we refer to B as a 1-bunch 
and if two joints are identified, then
we refer to B as a 2-bunch . Moreover, if B' âˆˆâ„¬ and V(B) âˆ© V(B') â‰ âˆ…, then V(B) âˆ© V(B') âŠ† V(T_H).


  (ii) If B is a 2-bunch, then there exists a brrb-path P_B=x_0x_1x_2x_3 in T_H  
such that either x_0, x_2, or x_1, x_3 are the joints of B. Moreover, 
if B' âˆˆâ„¬ and B â‰  B', then P_B â‰  P_B'. We say that the path P_B is occupied 
at x_0, x_2 (or at x_1, x_3) by B. Each brrb-path is occupied either at none, or at 2 vertices.


  (iii) For each brrb-path P_B=x_0x_1x_2x_3 occupied at x_0, x_2 
(symmetric condition in the case that P_B is occupied at x_1, x_3),
it holds that d_H(x_1)=2  and for H' = H-E(B) exactly one of the following properties is satisfied.

 
  * d_H'(x_0) â‰¥ 1, d_H'(x_2) = 2 and d_H'(x_3) â‰¥ 1 
 
  * d_H'(x_0) = 1, d_H'(x_2) > 2 and d_H'(x_3) â‰¥ 1. 
 
 
 
 In other words, itemÂ (iii) says that x_1  is neither the joint of a 1-bunch, nor 
 the joint of a building path of T_H, and that 
 joints of 1-bunches and joints of building paths of T_H may
 correspond either to x_0 and x_3, 
 or to x_2 and x_3 (namely, such joints cannot simultaneously correspond to x_0 and x_2).

If D is a distribution of pebbles on the graph G such that D(v)
â‰¥ 1 for every vertex v in V(G), then Ï€(G, D) is the smallest
number n with the property that if n pebbles are placed on a

sentence:
[Weak AMD code] 


Suppose (, , , E) is an AMD code.


  * The value Î”âˆˆâˆ–{0} is chosen according to the adversary's strategy.


  * The source s âˆˆ is chosen uniformly at random by the encoder
(i.e., we have equiprobable sources).

  * The source is encoded into g âˆˆ A(s) using the encoding function E.

  * The adversary  wins if and only if g + Î”âˆˆ A(s') for some s' â‰  s.

The success probability of the strategy Ïƒ, denoted 
Ïµ_Ïƒ, is the probability that the adversary wins this game using the
specific strategy Ïƒ.

We will say that the code (, , , E) is a weak (m,n,)-AMD code where
 denotes the success probability of the adversary's optimal 
strategy.

 denotes the success probability of the adversary's optimal 
strategy.

    = max _Ïƒ{Ïµ_Ïƒ} .
